repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - National System of Protected
            Areas Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the National System of
            Protected Areas Project for Ecuador were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was substantial, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and borrower performance was also moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: in designing
            participatory models for protected area management, the Bank
            needs to draw upon successful experiences in other
            countries. Support for protected areas needs to be based
            upon a careful analysis of their revenue and expenditure
            streams over time to estimate the minimum amount required
            for their sound management as part of the whole system.
            Non-profit, private sector institutions can serve the public
            interest by independently managing endowment funds for
            protected areas. Effective management of protected area
            systems requires sustainable financing to ensure basic
            operating costs are covered for all of the protected areas
            within the system

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - National System of Protected
            Areas Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the National System of
            Protected Areas Project for Ecuador were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory; the risk to development outcome
            was moderate; the Bank performance was satisfactory; and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: Business administration and management
            skills throughout the Patrimony of Protected Areas will
            increase the ability to deal with pressures on protected
            areas by extractive industries and other activities and to
            increase the protected areas' economic and financial
            potential. Since the initial operation of the global
            environmental facility (GEF), biodiversity projects have
            tried to demonstrate the important link between biodiversity
            conservation and economic development, including improved
            livelihoods and cost-effectiveness to mainstream
            conservation in national development planning and economic
            policies. Effort should continue to actually demonstrate
            such a linkage through real, replicable initiatives
            involving populations whose livelihoods mainly and directly
            depend on the sustainable use of natural resources. The
            protected areas management plans should become tools not
            only for planning, but to actually increase overall
            management efficiency. These plans should permit the
            establishment of a structure synchronizing actions made
            within the central ministry of environment (MAE) and within
            the distinct regions of MAE with the end goal of ensuring an
            efficient administration of the protected areas. A wider
            dissemination of the knowledge accumulated though such
            planning exercises will also help to ensure long-term
            commitment by key actors.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - National System of Protected
            Areas Project : Environmental Assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The National System of Protected Areas
            (NSPA) for Ecuador aims at strengthening the NSPA through
            improving the legal, institutional and financial foundations
            and capacities for the integrated, participatory management
            of protected areas. Identification of impacts and mitigation
            measures: in order to significantly reduce adverse
            environmental impacts, the most feasible and cost-effective
            measures will be proposed. This will allow to: i) identify
            all anticipated significant adverse impacts; and ii)
            describe and develop technical details of each mitigation
            measure, including an estimation of potential impacts of
            these measures. Environmental rules will be incorporated in
            the bidding documents or contracts and will cover the
            following aspects: the maintenance of systems of collection
            and disposal of solid and liquid wastes, including recycling
            systems and the classification of materials; materials
            procurement guidelines to avoid environmentally hazardous
            materials of the collection of construction materials from
            sensitive areas; prohibition of hunting, fishing, animal
            capture, plant collection or burning of vegetation.

TF038769-ECUADOR - PREPARATION OF
            RAINFOREST CONSERVATION PROJECT,TF021967-DUTCH PARTNERSHIP - BANK/WWF

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - National System of Protected
            Areas : resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The National System of Protected Areas
            (NSPA) for Ecuador seeks to consolidate an improve
            conservation efforts in three priority protected areas. The
            activities supported by the project for the conservation of
            biodiversity and tropical forests involve the empowerment of
            main stakeholders throughout local participation on
            environmental management and strengthening the national
            capacity for establishing process of sustainable
            development. The possibility remains that in order to
            consolidate and renew protected areas, some activities might
            affect the current livelihoods of people living within the
            protected areas or in their buffer zones. This process
            framework delineates the criteria and measures which NSPA
            will follow in such cases to ensure that the entitled,
            affected persons are assisted to restore, replace or improve
            their livelihood in an approach which maintains the
            environmental sustainability of the protected areas. The
            project will promote the participatory management according
            to the specific social and political conditions of each
            protected area. The project will address all indigenous
            issues in accordance with the World Bank's Safeguard
            Policies on Indigenous Peoples, as well as with the
            Ecuadorian Law. The project will seek to develop a
            constructive relation with the local indigenous communities
            living in the selected protected areas. The preparation
            and/or update of the PA management plans will give special
            importance to the integration of the priorities and demands
            established by the local and indigenous population through
            their development plans.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - National System of Protected
            Areas Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The National System of Protected Areas
            Project is to ensure the conservation and management of
            Ecuador's biodiversity for socially sustainable
            development. This project is the first phase of a four-year
            project. There are four project components. Component 1 aims
            to consolidate the role of the Directorate of Biodiversity
            and Protected Areas (DBPA) as the agency responsible for
            administering the National System of Protected Areas (NSPA).
            It will develop the regulatory framework to promote
            participatory management and co-management of PAs in the
            country.Sub-components include: 1) updating the NSPA
            strategic plan to coordinate DBAP long-term actions; 2)
            preparing a financial and managerial system for DBAP and
            implementing it in nine protected areas; 3) developing a
            sustainable financial strategy; 4) implementing pilot
            concessions of services; 5) designing and implementing a
            training program; 6) strengthening mechanisms for
            institutional coordination, participation, technical advice,
            and political support by civil society to manage and
            consolidate the NSPA; and 7) developing legal instruments.
            Component 2 promotes participatory management by developing
            participatory models according to the specific social and
            political conditions of each area. Component 3 is directed
            to achieve the consolidation of the Protected Areas Fund
            (FAP) that operates within the National Environmental Fund
            of Ecuador. Component 4 establishes a follow-up system to
            evaluate and monitor implementation.

2055803.trustfund:
TF038769-ECUADOR - PREPARATION OF
            RAINFOREST CONSERVATION PROJECT,TF021967-DUTCH PARTNERSHIP - BANK/WWF
            ALLIANCE (LCSES),TF023418-GEF2 : ECUADOR - NATIONAL

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - National System of Protected
            Areas Project : indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The National System of Protected Areas
            Project for Ecuador seeks to develop a constructive relation
            with the local indigenous communities living in the selected
            protected areas, as well as with their national
            representation entities. The Protected Areas Management
            plans will recognize the existing local development plans
            and/or indigenous development plans as a key step towards
            the recognition, valorization and protection of cultural
            resources and ancestral knowledge of the local and
            indigenous populations. In the formulation and/or update of
            the Protected Areas (PA) management plans, special
            importance will be given to the integration of the
            priorities and demands established by the local and
            indigenous population through their development plans.
            Toward this end, the project will work in close coordination
            with PRODEPINE, who is sponsoring indigenous development
            plans throughout the country. The project will seek
            technical assistance agreements to ensure the integration of
            indigenous peoples' demands in PA management.
            Throughout the implementation of the PA management plans,
            the project will ensure the incorporation of indigenous and
            local populations' knowledge, as well as sponsor
            sustainable natural resources, and production systems
            compatible with biodiversity conservation and management.
